title: 108_hr2909
content: The Act is titled the "Utah Test and Training Range Protection Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Act titled the "Utah Test and Training Range Protection Act" defines key terms such as "covered wilderness," "Tribe," "Utah Test and Training Range," and "Wilderness Act." The term "Wilderness Act" refers to Public Law 88-577, approved on September 3, 1964 (16 U.S.C. 1131 et seq.). SEC. 3. Military operations and overflights, Utah Test and Training Range. The Congress recognizes the importance of military testing and training for national security, with the Utah Test and Training Range being a crucial asset. The Cedar Mountain Wilderness Area and nearby lands play a role in supporting military missions at the range. The Act acknowledges the unique management circumstances of wilderness areas with withdrawn airspace for military use. It emphasizes that the Act should not set a precedent for future conservation areas. Access to the Utah Test and Training Range is a national security priority and can coexist with the protection of natural resources. Low-level military overflights are allowed over the covered lands. The Act allows for military activities such as helicopters, missiles, and unmanned aerial vehicles over the wilderness. It also permits the designation of special use airspace and training routes, as well as the maintenance and installation of communication and tracking systems for military testing and training in wilderness study areas. The Act allows for military activities over wilderness study areas located beneath special use airspace, including various designated units. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Secretary of the Air Force, must ensure compliance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act. Additionally, emergency access and response agreements between the Department of the Interior and the Department of the Air Force are not affected by this Act or the Wilderness Act. Prohibition on ground military operations in covered wilderness areas of the Utah Test and Training Range, unless permitted by Federal law and consistent with the Wilderness Act. SEC. 4. PLANNING PROCESS FOR FEDERAL LANDS IN UTAH TEST AND TRAINING RANGE. The Secretary of the Interior must develop, maintain, and revise land use plans for Federal lands in the Utah Test and Training Range in consultation with the Secretary of Defense. The Secretary of Defense must provide an analysis of military readiness and operational impacts for proposed revisions within six months of a request. The Secretary of the Interior is prohibited from granting rights-of-way on identified Federal lands. The Secretary of the Interior must develop, maintain, and revise land use plans for Federal lands in Utah, including specific inventory units, until the completion of a full revision of the Pony Express Area Resource Management Plan or January 1, 2015. SEC. 5. DESIGNATION AND MANAGEMENT OF CEDAR MOUNTAIN WILDERNESS, UTAH. The Federal lands in Tooele County, Utah, are designated as the Cedar Mountain Wilderness Area, withdrawn from various forms of use, and a map and legal description will be provided by the Secretary of the Interior. The Cedar Mountain Wilderness Area in Tooele County, Utah, will be administered by the Secretary of the Interior in accordance with the Wilderness Act. A map and legal description will be transmitted to the House Committee on Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, with the Secretary able to make corrections as needed. The map and legal description will be available for public inspection in the Bureau of Land Management offices in Utah. The Cedar Mountain Wilderness Area in Utah will be administered according to the Wilderness Act. Lands acquired after the enactment of this Act will be added to the wilderness area. State jurisdiction over fish and wildlife on federal lands in Utah will not be affected. Grazing of livestock established before the enactment of this Act will be allowed in the wilderness area. The Cedar Mountain Wilderness Area will allow grazing of livestock established before the enactment of the Act, subject to reasonable regulations. Congress does not intend to create buffer zones around the wilderness area. Nonwilderness activities or uses visible or audible within the area will not be prohibited up to the boundary. The Browns Spring Cherrystem lands are released from wilderness study area status, no longer subject to specific management requirements. SEC. 6. Additional Bureau of Land Management land in Utah identified as trust land for Skull Valley Band of Goshutes. The Secretary of the Interior will identify 640 acres of Bureau of Land Management land in Utah to be held in trust for the Skull Valley Band of Goshutes. The land must have access to highways and be suitable for economic development. By December 31, 2005, the land will be placed in trust for economic development purposes. The Secretary of the Interior will identify 640 acres of Bureau of Land Management land in Utah for the Skull Valley Band of Goshutes' economic development. The land will be placed in trust, managed according to trust laws, and reverts to Bureau of Land Management if sold by the Tribe. No existing rights on the land will be affected. The trust land placed in trust for the Tribe under subsection (c) cannot enlarge, impair, or affect any existing rights or claims of the Tribe to land based on Aboriginal or Indian title. It also cannot reserve water rights for any purpose or affect any existing water rights of the Tribe. SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LANDS AND LAWS. This Act does not impact Federal lands outside the covered wilderness. Section 2815 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2000 is amended by removing subsection (d).
